subject: Re: About the value of JUnit

messageBody:
> Or I can pay $0 for a set of tools (JUnit, Anthill, Ant) to allow
me to
> write Java code to test my classes, automatically run the tests,
and
> report on the results via the GUIs of my choice.
>
> Its a tradeoff that reasonable people can disagree on. "What's
the
> value in the automatic generation of test cases?" I know which
way I
> currently lean, but that's not to say that my choice is right for
everyone.
>

You will spend much more time writing JUnit tests manually and
maintaining
them than writing and maintaining DbC and performing tests
automatically.

I think that as a JUnit/TDD user you write tests 50% of the time you
write
code. Thats a lot.

Besides this, JTest is much more powerful in testing capabilities.

And using DbC, you have a nice documentation by the way, of much
more value
than cumbersome, knotty and unnatural test code.

I still have to examine both of them, the free JUnit and the
commercial
JTest.

I'm still open, but I favor DbC based solutions for testing at this
point.
